number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												While the base game isn't much, the true power comes from the expansions. All expansions are made to work in synergy with the other and create more content exponentially linked to the number of expansions you have.So the base game + supernatural + ambitions means the ambitions system now works for supernatural careers like alchemist and unlocks "synergy content." Without ambitions, the system wont be there for supernatural.As your game grows, the synergy content grows as well. When you own all the major expansions (not the stuff packs), you get an absolutely massive amount of synergy content.So far here are the expansions:Ambitions - adds interactive jobs, new jobs centering around craft skills. Adds scrap metal robots that become obsolete when you get into the future. Adds scrap yard, fire station, and other job based commecial lots.pets - adds pets. Nothing special. Not much synergy content. Requires NRAAS mods or the wild life bogs down your game. Adds pet park commercial lots.into the future - this is VERY unbalanced and practically cheating. You can create overpowered sim-bots that can max every skill, then teach your kids those skills or craft an infinite amount of high end items. They can even hold max level jobs meaning a single sim bot turns the sims into easy mode permenantly since sim bots dont age. Adds futuristic commercial lots like a future lounge, a fancy bar run by robots.University - this adds social groups, "drugs", alcohol, multiple commercial lots like coffee shops, comic book stores, and bowling alleys. Adds plant sims. Adds science skill, and science objects like the science station. In here, you can clone practically anything and everyone. You also The science objects here are overpowered. You can even buy a brain enhancer to respec your entire personality whenever you want, even random strangers. This expansion also adds social networking, where you run a website and gain followers based on what you do. For instance, talking to a ghost and blogging about it is good content. This applies for other expansions as well, where you can boast about a good performance in show time or a cleared dungeon in world adventures. A good blogger can also get famous in late night.Seasons - This adds seasons that tie into other expansions. Island Paradise resorts are effected by what season it is. No one will want to go to a resort in the snowy winter. Adds aliens, and alien technology like the weather controller and UFO car that you can use to terrorize the city.Supernatural - adds supernatural creatures,  huge addition to  crafting ingredients, lunar cycle, and magic. The lunar cycle means that 1 night means there is a full moon, which means all sorts of supernatural creatures come out like zombies. This sounds cool, but it turns into an annoyance. The zombies become loud, annoying hobos on your porch after a while. Adds supernural lots like the vampire lounge (fancy bar), and the werewolf bar.late night - adds fame, which ties into all other expansions. Adds even more powers to vampires. Adds nightlife commercial lots that tie into the commercial lots of all the other expansions.Island paradise - adds all sorts of water activities, boats, house boats, and the ability to run a resort or hotel. Adds mermaid sims. NOTICE: YOU NEED NRAAS BUG FIXES TO USE THE ISLAND PARADISE NEIGHBORHOOD WITHOUT ISSUE.Generations - adds a whole bunch of rewards based on what you do in your sim's life. Adds a bunch of inspiration rewards for living a good life, often in overpowered items. Adds another science object, the chemistry set that is  just as overpowered as the other items from university.world adventures - you travel the world, complete dungeons, and if you have late night you can get famous doing it. Adds objects from Egypt, France, and China. It adds TONS of rare and expensive collectibles including rebuilt sarcophigi, statues, and dive wells. A good haul of artifacts can make you a very rich, or the museum very profitable if you own it. Adds mummy sims.show time - ties into late night. adds performance careers. Adds genies. adds a whole bunch of items that should have been in late night like the DJ booth.It all depends on what you want from your sims.CONS:HUGE LOAD TIMES WHEN YOU LOAD ANY NEIGHBORHOOD.VERY CPU INTENSIVE GAME, WITH ALL THE EXPANSIONS AN INTEL I5 2500 HAS PROBLEMS KEEPING UP DUE TO THE GAME LOADING EVERYTHING AT ONCE LIKE IN THE CAS MENU.NEEDS NRAAS BUG FIXES TO WORK MOST OF THE TIME.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												I have always been a fan of The Sims ever since the first Sims PC game was created back in the early 2000s. I loved the Sims 2 so I decided to buy TS3. I like how you are able to do a lot more things in TS3. The developers really listened to the fans by adding in new features and touches such as;                +Able to move camera freely around the environment and town                +Can watch your sim visit the park or travel down town                +Gives more options and tools to design home                +Can create basements                +Can design countertops with many items instead of just one item Downside for me;;                -It'll be nice if other sims you created would progress as you play other created sim families. Its not like in TS2 where you can create different families and watch them grow old while playing other families. Despite the downside, I still like TS3. You can always download mods and many other things to make your gaming experience realistic and fun-which is why I love Sim games.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												If you want a Sims game, but don't want.. as many loading times, this is the one you want.The Sims 3 was around a long time. Building on the Wishes mechanic of the second game, this one has Lifetime Rewards, where you can gain points for keeping moodlets high and fufilling their various desires.These points can be cashed in at any point.Personally, I recommend getting the Supernatural and Late Night expansion packs if you like cities, and like an easier way to be immortal but still allow aging. Being a vampire is pretty fun.Late Night adds a small city to play in, which admittedly feels a bit... empty. You'll want to play custom towns off the Sims3modding website.Beyond that... Sims 3 is a mostly open world, non-instanced Sims game. It has problems, sure, it's buggy, it can do a lot of things at once meaning when you save your game it takes forever, you will find horses hanging around a single empty lot if you have pets.Also, don't get seasons: much of the weather effects are really resource intensive and may kill your game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5
												Excellent guilty pleasure game and man, what a time sink this game can be. The game has an excellent modding community as well. I recommend waiting for steam sales before you buy any of the DLC though, and stay away from the "stuff packs" they are generally not worth getting, especially for the price.One important thing to note is that the loading times in this game, as well as the time it takes to save are unforgiveably bad, I recommend putting the game into windowed mode and then forcing it into windowed borderless with the windowed borderless gaming software so you can tab out and do something else while it loads / saves. Thankfully the game only has to load once since it is open world (unless you are traveling to a new neighbourhood, then it needs to load the new neighbourhood as well)Before you start playing The Sims 3 I strongly recommend you get some important mods, nraas overwatch as well as nraas debugger. Overwatch will do a check and cleanup of your game neighbourhood once ever 24 hours to fix the awful performance that plagues this otherwise great game and fix sims getting stuck etc. Debugger will allow you to wiggle around other bugs and issues you run into, it will basically allow you to do anything for debugging purposes.Enjoy the game!

content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
												Sims 2 is still my favorite Sims game because, with DLC, you can make some very realistic looking characters and surroundings and animations,  therefore, more immersive gameplay. However, Sims 3 has a beautiful open world and some good added customization options. The chracters just look more cartoony than the DLC-customized Sims 2 characters. Sims 3 is a good game and I paid ten times as much as the 5 it is now on sale for plus over 200-300 on all of the added expansion and stuff packs. I bought everything for Sims 2 as well back in the day and don't regret any of it a bit. All that said, Sims 4 is horrible and I actually only bought the base game and quickly refunded it which was super disappointing because I have been an avid fan having spent over a thousand bucks on the franchise since the advent of Sims 1. If you like life simulators and don't have this yet, I highly recommend that you buy Sims 3, especially at this current ridiculously low sale price!!

A good haul of artifacts can make you a very rich, or the museum very profitable if you own it. Adds mummy sims.show time - ties into late night. adds performance careers. Adds genies. adds a whole bunch of items that should have been in late night like the DJ booth.It all depends on what you want from your sims.CONS:HUGE LOAD TIMES WHEN YOU LOAD ANY NEIGHBORHOOD.VERY CPU INTENSIVE GAME, WITH ALL THE EXPANSIONS AN INTEL I5 2500 HAS PROBLEMS KEEPING UP DUE TO THE GAME LOADING EVERYTHING AT ONCE LIKE IN THE CAS MENU.NEEDS NRAAS BUG FIXES TO WORK MOST OF THE TIME.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												The Sims is a "people simulator", which puts you in control of a neighborhood, dictating the personal lives of the residents one household at a time.  It is, I believe, the best-selling game series of all time, despite being a niche market.  It is an awkward game to explain from a gaming standpoint, as design Will Wright found when he pitched the series in the 90's.  The Sims 3 makes a number of changes that in hindsight seem so obvious and address issues in the previous versions.  Some examples:*Aging is now optional and adjustable.  You have the option of turning sim aging off (like The Sims 1), or having it on (like The SIms 2), and you can change the length of each age.  *Story progression, also optional.  Now the neighbors who are not actively being played will carry on their lives without your input.  They will age, marry, have children, get jobs, and other things on their own.  *Moodlets replace the previous method of tying emotional state directly to needs.  Now situations dictate emotions (and needs are just one trigger of moodlets).  This has a lot of great advantages, because it takes the emphasis off gaming the needs stats and onto the character's interactions.*Personalities expand on the previous aspiration system, with each sim gaining a number of personality traits that determine moodlets, learning, abilities, and many other aspects of their lives.  *Interactions between all of these systems make interesting results.  You can watch a lifelong feud between a Good personality-sim and an Evil personality-sim unfold, where their mood drops just be being around each other.  One strange decision, however, is locking the focus on a single household.  Previously, you could freely switch families during a session, but while this is still possible, the game makes it a little awkward.  Sims 3 is designed for you to focus on a single house for most of the game.  The worst thing about this game is DLC and microtransation creep.  The Sims 2 had a lot of expansions, and experimented with an online store eventually, but The Sims 3 truly went all out.  There are endless expansions, stuff packs, and an online story for buying clothes and objects.  I am not even sure it is possible to own the complete content of The Sims 3.  On the other hand, the variety of extra content allows you to customize the game to your liking.  You don't have to play Supernatural or get Katy Perry stuff if you would rather have Pets and 80's nostalgia.  Personally, with the addition of some mods (like Overwatch and Story Progression), I consider this the most interesting version of The Sims, especially if you are interested in the neighborhood story.  Just remember DLC creep is optional...

content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
												Sims 2 is still my favorite Sims game because, with DLC, you can make some very realistic looking characters and surroundings and animations,  therefore, more immersive gameplay. However, Sims 3 has a beautiful open world and some good added customization options. The chracters just look more cartoony than the DLC-customized Sims 2 characters. Sims 3 is a good game and I paid ten times as much as the 5 it is now on sale for plus over 200-300 on all of the added expansion and stuff packs. I bought everything for Sims 2 as well back in the day and don't regret any of it a bit. All that said, Sims 4 is horrible and I actually only bought the base game and quickly refunded it which was super disappointing because I have been an avid fan having spent over a thousand bucks on the franchise since the advent of Sims 1. If you like life simulators and don't have this yet, I highly recommend that you buy Sims 3, especially at this current ridiculously low sale price!!

Go to a house that is huge, so that you know the people who live in it are rich. Go inside, meet a girl. It doesn't matter how old, as long as they are out of high school. Flirt with them until you guys become romantic interests. Don't forget to do a lot of romance/flirt interactions with them to make this happen quicker. It usually takes about 5 minutes to get them from stranger to romantic interest. Then, invite them over to your house. Relax on the bed, and invite her over to cuddle. Go to interactions, hit more, and hit try for baby. MAKE THAT ♥♥♥♥♥ PREGNANT. Don't worry, it won't cost you any money. At the moment I have 9 kids with 7 different woman, and I haven't met any of them. Make sure you try for the baby at least 5 times, so that'll guarantee that she gets pregnant. The upside of that is so when she gives birth, your mood goes way up. Next, go to romance and hit "propose going steady". She'll say yes, because you're a ♥♥♥♥ing MAC DADDY, then go to the same place and hit propose marriage. She won't give a ♥♥♥♥ that you just became boyfriend/girlfriend, you're a ♥♥♥♥ing mac daddy and she says yes. She'll move in with you, and you get all of her money and her car if she has one. She usually has around 10k that you get and a car that sells for 5-16k. This whole process will take you about 10 minutes. After you get married, make sure to try for a baby a couple times again, just to be sure.Last, interact with her, go to mean and hit break up. After about a minute, you realize all these ♥♥♥♥♥es aren't worth your time. You'll break up, and your mood will go down a bit, but not for long because she was a colossal♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ All you need to do now is hit her face on the side to take control of her sim, that go to her cellphone, call the realtor, and hit move. Once you are on the move screen, check the box that says kick out, and rename her new house. It will be your last name by default, but that ♥♥♥♥♥ DOES NOT deserve the honor of having your last name. I named my first ex-wife's new house Cun!t, then the rest I just named Ex-Wife #2, #3, #4, #5, #6, #7, #8, #9, #10, and much much more. Now just repeat this multiple times and soon enough you'll be living in a mansion with the most expensive stuff. If only it worked like this in real life.10/10

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Story of Craig Adams:Craig was a simple man. He had no life, no job, no girl and no family. He didn't realise his loneliness but one day, he became controlled by a mysterious person called "The Player". Craig was scared, the player started changing his personality and clothing. The player said "I'm gonna make you a success". Craig was excited and he soon found a job after playing CoD. After his first day he met a girl who he got on pretty well with until he found out she was married and Craig beat her up (because of the player). Craig met another girl and they became good friends. Eventually Craig invited her over and that's when things went to the extreme. Craig lost his virginity and became a father. After that, his girlfriend had a baby girl and Craig had his birthday. Craig and the player knew that he needed to get married so Craig asked his girlfriend on a date and proposed. The wedding was only two minutes and Craig had a family. As one last goodbye, Craig thanked the player and lived his life. Craig is now dead. The end.

												Honestly, the only thing I wish this game did was give the player the ability to build homes without having to first create a household. Design and architecture are things that really interest me, and I love creating and designing houses, but it's tedious to have to first build Sims. Sure, I could speed through that process by choosing Randomize, but I would still have to wait through at least two long loading screens. I wish this wasn't necessary. Sometimes, I just want to build a house.Other than that, I like Sims 3 better than Sims 4. Sims 3 is pretty straight-forward for a new player to get into and there is a good deal of DLC that sometimes is very inexpensive (note: always wait for the sales; $20 for a single DLC for a game that's nearly ten years old is kind of ridiculous) that add a lot to the game.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												Pretty fun sequel. They did a nice job of getting your sims out of the house and into town. The vanilla version though I think is pretty low on content in some areas, too few hair, clothing and accessories to choose from. But the customization options for almost everything in-game is very very well done. You can take a wallpaper and change it to look like metal, or take a car and make it look like a wooden toy. I always loved building my own house in Sims, and in Sims 3 I got more room for creativity than ever. The "face-generator" could use some work though, as many sims look very much alike. Shamefully many DLC though, at shamefully high prices. Not cool.  But I have my hopes for the future of the series. Maybe nr 4 will allow me to truly build a palace, and make the game harder in some way, I found it way too easy to build a fortune and make friends in this game.Anyways, a good SIMS game.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												Been meaning to write a little review for a couple of years now and finally i can. Having played the Sims from day one i have watched the Sims evolve over the years and each game is more and more fun to play. You can play the game properly and try and achieve your Sims needs or if your feeling chaotic like myself at times you can create families and just cause havoc and watch them fall apart in messy households running riot. Its also a game my girlfriend and myself can play at the same time, i make the money and do all the hard part and she spends it on customizing parts of the house and garden or buys the next sized house for us to do up haha. There are many many DLC packs for the Sims 3, some that are fun and others that wouldnt interest me but thats ultimately down to personal choice. Sims 3 and Sims pets is all we need to have a laugh for a few hours here and there! Looking forward to the Sims4. I hope this helps some of you that may be considering buying this, any more questions feel free to message me! Peace

content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
AUDIOPoorVISUALPeppyDIFFICULTYN/AVIBEEscapistCRAVINGCustomizationON SALEInfrequentlyPROS:  Unlike Sims 4, 2 and 3 was a big leap in features, graphics and content. There is so much that can happen, and the city continues to move even if you're just watching the events of one household. Building homes has been drastically improved, very gorgeous results can be obtained.CONS: Cash shop features have snuck into the series, a nauseating and unfortunately effective addition. Third party is invasive even after the splash screen?? Why? The biggest thing for me is the music; The Sims 1 had one of the best soundtracks, a series of hilariously peppy muzak renditions that filled the game with a  so the soulless feel of the newer ones is worth mourning. WORTH: Pricing for expansions is absolutely asinine, and they don't go on sale often. $379.00USD for all DLC of a game released in 2009? Insanity. Still, when they DO go on sale, they go up to 75% off! Your patience will be rewarded.OVERALL: If you like to build a world, this is the ultimate sandbox to play in. If you can step around all the microtransactions, you will find underneath, a spectacular game worth hours of your time.SCORE: 7/10                                                                     Full Review Coming Soon

												One word: motherlodeSeriously though apart from the guilt factor of spending so much time on creating your Sim and house when you should be, you know, reading a book or going outside, this is a great game. Of course it's laggy and you don't get steam achievements but it's Sims what do you expect? Just be thankful you have it on PC and not the unspeakable disgrace on consoles. Because, occasional lag aside, this is the best game EA has to offer in my eyes and you can't help but laugh at the glitches, faces, "memories" and letters. Then cry when the one decent Sim in your town befrriends you but then gets a boyfriend. Then rejoice with the ability to add to existing family thanks to testingcheatsenabled true. Rejected in real life? Sims is for you!Bored of real life? Sims is for you!Hate the Sims? SIMS IS FOR YOU! Want to waste countless hours on letting your sims live the dream (or watching them suffer)? Sims is for you!My faviourite way to play the game is creating a dream life for myself with some comedic relief in the background. I'm glad no one has asked why a white young adult is living with a fat black man in a hotdog suit.See I'm nice I don't steal AI's wives and make them my own. I find a decent girl, give her a makeover if need be then become married the slow, right and proper way.....ctrl+shift+c testingcheatsenabled true edit: relationship status.Signed,An illegitimate legitimate Sims player who only started buying Sims once Sims 3 Gold gave me viruses. content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
												I have been playing The Sims since game one, since they came out, and have loved following its progression over the years. It's an incredible game full of choices and you can do pretty much anything you want all the time. It's amazing, endless hours of fun packed into this game.HOWEVER.EA is **** evil. Not only are you getting robbed completely blind if you actually want all of the expasions, but the game itself is SO. FREAKING. GLITCHY. In between invisible Sims, some expansion packs literally just not working at all, corrupted save files, the game literally crashing for no reason whatsoever every two hours or so...I've spent more time creating new save files, uninstalling and reinstalling the game, or searching forums for solutions to various glitches. I can't play without cheats on because I'm constantly using the 'resetSim firstnamelastname' cheat because I glitch into a wall/ceiling/floor/building/fellow Sim/turn invisible/etc. EA gives zero craps about their consumers. They do not care about anyone but themselves and lining their pockets. I wish to God that a different producer, who actually thought about the players...EVER...had made this game, because I love it to death, but EA will just throw out endless unfinished and completely broken games and expansions, and will do absolutely nothing to fix it. Buy nothing from EA unless you want to get royally screwed.EDIT: Did the math. I have about $220 worth of their product, from expansions. Was it worth? Well, I'll give that the same answer to this question...does it actually function? NO.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2013
												I used to be a huge fan of this series, and I kind of have a love-hate relationship with it. I can even remember watching my mother playing Sims 1 when I was like, three. When I played Sims 2, I owned every EP. I once was able to call this my absolute favorite series, until I came to the realization that the game plus all the expansion packs cost around $400, and as amazing as the game is, I don’t think $400 is worth it. It’s extremely difficult to play this game and not drool over the expansion packs, so I just kind of stopped playing it. I recommend this game if you have amazing self-control, or have $400 to waste. Don’t get me wrong, hours of fun are to be had with this excellent game, but the fact is that the developers and publishers are evil when it comes to the EPs. Even though playing as a vampire fireman who aspires to be a stunt double, living with robots, racists, and poodles, then watching them all try to kill each other is amazing, $400 for the full experience? ♥♥♥♥ you EA.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												I must say that I do love the Sims as a franchise. And yes, I will admit that having to pay for multiple little cool things in a game is a horrible idea. But the base game alone is worth adding to your collection of games. It is a unique simulation and can provide some expirimental, time-wasting fun. And it also provides a great base for the modding communtiy to get their creativity on. But without the mods or certain expansion packs, I must admit that it is a very lack-luster and thinly spread game. Comparing the base game to either a modded game or a game with all of the expansions and "stuff packs", it is an overly-simply good idea than anything else. Creativity is at play, yet the microtransactions are strong in this one. I'd make sure to download many mods and to turn off the in-game payment system in the Options to get a very true and personal experience with this fun simulator.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												Twilight begins with an unnamed narrator (whom we later find out is Bella) giving a brief account about how she is about to die at the hands of a hunter. She is dying in the place of someone she loves, and the narrator does not regret any of the choices that brought her to this point. The past few months have been extraordinary, and she can’t complain.Zip! Now we’re following the life of Isabella “Bella” Swan, our seventeen-year-old narrator. Bella is moving to Forks, Washington, to live with her dad. We later learn that she volunteered to do this so that she wouldn’t hold her mother back from spending more time with her mother’s new husband. Forks is isolated, cold, dreary, and wet, and Bella’s relationship with her dad is distant, since she was raised by her mother in Phoenix. Bella's new life is dull until she gets a glimpse of the Cullen family – five gorgeous, mesmerizing siblings who attend her high school. She learns they do not socialize with anyone but each other. One of the boys in particular, Edward, pays her close attention and seems to regard her with alarming hostility when she's forced to sit next to him in Biology class. The next day, he is absent from school.Bella continues to adapt to her new life in Forks. She gets a lot more attention from boys than she was used to in Phoenix. She makes several friends quickly. A few days later, Edward finally is back in school. Now he’s friendly to Bella. His mere presence excites her. That afternoon in the school parking lot, a boy’s truck almost hits Bella after skidding on some black ice, but Edward uses his body as a shield in order to save her. Wait, how’d he do that?! Bella is totally baffled by this, but Edward refuses to explain his inhuman strength. She begins to have dreams about Edward, but at school, he gives her the cold shoulder. His behavior is very confusing, indeed.Bella gets asked to the upcoming school dance by not one, but three boys, all of whom she rejects. The next day, Edward gets Bella to talk to him during lunch – for the first time he’s spending lunch apart from his siblings. Knowing that she's trying to make sense of his strength and how he saved her, Edward asks for her “theories” on him. Next, it’s let’s-figure-out-your-blood-type day in Biology class, and Edward’s skipping class. Bella becomes faint at the mere thought of blood, and gets taken to the nurse’s office (Edward appears outside and intercepts her from Mike, one of the guys who has a crush on Bella). Edward insists that he take her home.That weekend, during a trip to a beach at La Push Indian reservation, Bella meets Jacob Black, who tells her about “the cold ones” (vampires). Word around the reservation is that the Cullens are vampires. When Bella gets home, she does some internet research and things start falling into place. Bella decides that she’s too in love with Edward to resist him, even if he is a vampire.Soon after, Bella takes a trip to Port Angeles with a few friends, where she gets lost looking for a bookstore. Some thugs almost attack her in a dark alley, but Edward appears in his shiny Volvo and saves her. They have dinner together, and he drives her home. He reveals that yes, he is a vampire. Edward doesn’t want to be a monster, though, and actually only drinks the blood of animals. Bella knows now that he does thirst for her blood, yet she still is in love with him. Edward repeatedly warns Bella that she should be afraid of him and stay away, if she’s smart.Edward and Bella take a mini-field trip together and spend the afternoon in a nearby secluded meadow, where Edward shows Bella that his skin sparkles in the sun (which is why vampires only come out at night or on cloudy days, which are common in Forks). They are completely in love. They kiss for the first time. Bella learns more about Edward’s family and their past. Edward struggles with abiding his morals (not tempting himself by getting close to a human) versus what he desires – to be near Bella. Edward spends the night in Bella's bedroom, watching over her as she sleeps (without her dad knowing, of course). Bella visits Edward’s house, meets his family, and learns more about their “kind” – vampires who don’t feast on humans. They go back to her house where Jacob and his father Billy Black show up to see her dad (Billy and Charlie are friends). Being a Quileute elder from the La Push reservation, Billy knows about the Cullens' secret and is worried for Bella's safety. He warns her to stay away from the Cullens. After the Blacks leave, Edward returns in his brother's jeep to pick up Bella. They’re going to play baseball. It's a Cullen family bonding ritual, evidently.While the Cullens are playing their crazy version of baseball (they're all incredibly strong and fast), three other vampires show up. One named James takes a liking to Bella (in the “I want to eat you” kind of way). Edward and his family get Bella away from James long enough to make a plan. They know that James is trying to track Bella, so Alice and Jasper (Edward's adoptive siblings) whisk her away to a hiding place in Phoenix, but James lures Bella to him by telling her that he has captured her mom. He’s about to kill Bella when the Cullen clan shows up. The only problem is that James has already bitten Bella. If Edward doesn't suck the venom-infected blood out of her, she'll become a vampire. Though it's difficult for Edward to control his urge to suck all of Bella's blood, he manages to cure Bella without killing her. The Cullens kill James and get Bella to a hospital, where she starts to recover from her many injuries. Overall Bella’s OK, though banged up. She and Edward are more in love than ever. However, they argue because Bella wants him to bite her and make her into a vampire so that they can live together forever; Edward refuses. Regardless of their different species, they are devoted to one another completely.In the Epilogue, Edward surprises Bella by taking her to the prom – she's horrified because she's uncoordinated and worried about dancing in public. Jacob shows up at the dance and delivers a message – Billy wants Bella to dump Edward. He also wants her to know that they “will be watching” (Epilogue.118). Anyway, Edward and Bella go outside to have some time alone – it’s twilight outside. Again, Bella asks Edward to make her into a vampire, and he refuses. Edward says to Bella, “I will stay with you – isn’t that enough?” and she replies, “Enough for now” (Epilogue.204).

												Without Custom content, and Expansions, there really isn't much to go with, as far as choices go with customization, if you don't want to pay for all of the microtransactions in the game for extra content, and customization. I'm kind of torn between the thumbs up, or down. Big sims fan, not so big a fan on the costs. Most of the expansions and stuff packs cost more than the base game, which, in my opinion is kind of a flop, and I often end up just going back to Sims 2, and the millions of expansions I had for it. It costs a pretty penny, and I guess it's worth it for the Residential/Community building aspects,  (The diagonal walls with the flooring sticking out is fixed! FINALLY!!) I'm sure it would be even better if I had the hundreds of dollars for all the expansions and stuff packs. Overall, out of ten, I give a score of 7/10Meh, Could have been better.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												I'm a huge fan of the The Sims franchise, so it comes as no surprise that I enjoy this game. However, maybe this review is useful to someone already familiar with the series.There are several aspects about this iteration of the series that I dislike and which make me continue to view The Sims 2 as my favorite. I absolutely abhor having to see paid content in-game without having any interest whatsoever in ever buying it. I already spent more than $100 dollars on the base game and DLC. Why would I be charged for more and what justifies charging for it? Server maintenance, updates, and the cost of a Community Team (does The Sims even have one?) should be more than covered by that. So, besides the major issues of microtransactions being forced down one's throat, it also appears that getting free community content is much more of a hassle.  For starters, there is no Body Shop that allows you to easily create Sims and package them. There is no denying that the new Create a Sim tools are much more evolved and allow for much more customization, especially the ability to modify a Sim's body type, and the addition of true personality traits and combinations are great. However, there doesn't appear to be an easy way to share and obtain community content outside of EA's platform. I could list various other things that bother me about the game (e.g. Why are younger Sims so ugly? Why add rabbit holes?), but I think the attempts at money-making and sharing limitations are the main downsides to me.On the bright side, the graphics are beautiful and the exploration options endless, especially with the DLC (which, I am sorry to say, one still has to get for a more complete game experience).

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7
												Sims 3 is a fun, enjoyable game that I have spent countless hours playing. I would like to be able to 100% recommend the game, as it is a virtual world with unlimited options and customization, however, there are also reasons why I wouldn’t recommend it. I’m choosing to not recommend it, and this is not because the game itself isn’t good, it is because of the numerous glitches and issues that come along with the game. I have been a fan of sims for years, and have Sims 2 Pets for Game Cube, Sims 3 for Wii and Sims 3 for PC. Out of these three, Sims 2 was the only one that didn’t have a lot of glitches. There were some small ones, but nothing that makes the game unplayable. However, in both the Wii version and PC version of Sims 3, while the game starts out being relatively glitch free, as you progress through the storyline, the glitches gradually become more frequent and begin to affect the fun of the gameplay itself. As of three or four years ago, I had to stop playing the Sims 3 for Wii, because every time I would try to load the game, within two or three minutes in live mode, it would freeze completely. I purchased Sims 3 last year during the summer sale, along with the Pets expansion. There was a special offer that meant I was able to buy both for way less than the normal price. That was the only reason I even considered buying the game.I love Sims, don’t get me wrong, but given that I know how many glitches were in Sims 3 for the Wii, I wasn’t willing to spend full price on a game that may or may not be playable at some point in the future. To give you an idea of the types of glitches I have encountered, I will first of all list all the expansions that I have currently.I have:Sims 3 PetsSims 3 GenerationsSims 3 SupernaturalSims 3 University LifeSims 3 SeasonsSims 3 AmbitionsI got the other expansion packs at the beginning of this year, again on sale. The game, while it often lagged a lot, worked relatively well until the beginning of February, when a strange and very frustrating glitch occurred. I was trying to get my sim to walk to the fridge to get some food, but every time I tried to issue the command, the bubble indicating that they can’t go there came up. My fridge was in the same exact spot as it had been since I started playing that save file. I couldn’t figure out why my sim couldn’t get to the fridge, given that there wasn’t anything visibly in front of the fridge door. So, after trying to remove the invisible object, I decided to move my fridge one spot to the left. I issued the command to my sim again, and they simply walked over and completed the task. However, the fact that there was some kind of invisible object blocking access to half my kitchen still remained, for which I couldn’t find a permanent solution. There were other annoying glitches as well, but for the PC version, this was the one that really made me frustrated, because while I could just move houses, I had everything in my current house the way I wanted it and I didn’t want to have to buy a new house because of some invisible object. This, in addition to the numerous issues I have encountered with the Wii version as well as the PC version is what caused me to get so frustrated. Sims 3 would be an extremely fun game, but the enjoyment of playing it is greatly diminished by the glitches that interfere with the gameplay. In conclusion, I do not recommend the Sims 3 game, unless you are willing to deal with the problems that will more than likely occur the more you play the game. I wish the developers of the game would have taken more time and effort to smooth out the issues instead of trying to get it done quickly in order to be able to sell it to the public. Quality is always more important than quantity.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												So SOOOOOOOO buggy.  You have to play with cheats enabled.  You need cheats to repair your sims regularly as per official EA policy.  The longer your game lasts the worse it gets.  The game like to crash, and there is no auto-save meaning you can lose hours of game-play.  The game makes very poor use of your RAM. Every time you edit your sims home the game has to stop and reload textures for each item you modify, even for identical items.  The game also fails to clear your RAM properly so you need to restart your computer every 3 hours to maintain smooth animation.The game regularly suffers from broken AI, disappearing objects and Sims falling through floors.  Those are the least annoying bugs.  A game for sadists and masochists alike.

Posted: December 31, 2015
												They still need to fix how they do the military career, army would make way more sense then the airforce (larger, more popular and generic), and the astronaught would make more sense in a different line of the science career path. But yeah, this game is 10/10 for me. This game is a good real life simulator (don't judge by my time played, I've logged hundreds of hours on the Sims 2 and have played this game elsewhere), the only real problems are the ones in the other Sims games, but isn't much of a problem. If you want more detail on why it's great, look for Hess's review (or whatever his name is when you read this), he tells you on why it's such a good game in more detail. But in the end, if you like to simulate life, play God, or just torture your Sims (we've all done that at least once, don't lie), then this game is for you. However, if you DON'T like simulator games, like fast paced stuff, or are just new to the franchise, it may be hard to get into. Admittedly, I have trouble playing sometimes becuase there isn't enough action like in other games. Still, though, when their is a Steam Sale, I suggest trying it out at least.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Am I the only one who likes to make a bunch of Sims, name them after people I know, give them the same main personality characteristics as my irl friends, then watch what derpy things they do in game and see how they do when left to their own devices?  ENDLESS AMUSEMENT. (And sometimes, when the pixel SIM starts to become too much like the IRL friend...a little scary). This game brings back so many good memories of playing the early SIMs games, but the graphics are tons better than they used to be and the personalities are much more amusing (and the SIMs have more refined palates than before--making carbonara, mac and cheese, salads, and even cooking for pets.)  I like that you can play the game without really needing to avail yourself of the RMT store, too, and the SIMs will be plenty happy.  You can also control how quickly they age...and they will age...the addition of inevitable (as opposed to self-inflected by derping into a ladderless pool bwahhaha) mortality in the series makes the god complex you get playing the game all the better.  10/10

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												Sims 1: Has OK Graphics (Although crappy when you look at it now), gives you a decent start to a life simulatorSims 2: Awesome game, Awesome graphics, had more actions and scenes in which made it really better than the first one (And did I mention better graphics?)Sims 3: More customization to sims (traits favorites, etc), GREAT build mode, online store to buy stuff with Simpoints, has aspects from both Sims 1 and 2 on it (Except for scenes which made Sims 2 really awesome), you can control how long sims live and interact in the city and not have to wait through a loading screen every. freaking. time.Sims 4: Basically everything up above, but focuses more on your sims body customization and feelings. (You can move body parts around to suit your liking) (Haven't plsyed it to an extent because i only got a free trial on origin)My rating for this game? Asides from the Sims 2, DEFINITELY A SOLID 10/10 this is basically the best thing that ever happened in pc/console gaming since the sequel.WARNING: Once you start playing the sims, there is no coming out, you will be lifeless (HAHAHA, you get the joke? eh? eh?), so be cautious on how you play this game.  IT WILL TAKE OVER YOUR MIND.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1
												Made a werewolf guy (supernatural DLC) who's hot-headed, fearless, and cocky, and a vampire woman who is composed, proper, and a neat-freak live in a house together. Naturally, they clash at first: she can't stand how he leaves his dishes everywhere and runs around on all fours sometimes, while he finds her stuck up and pretentious. But over time, they start chatting more and realizing how much they have in common.Their friendship hits a rough patch at the full moon, when he transforms and ruins a bunch of furniture, and she goes a little nuts and attacks him (apparently there's an action called a "lunatic slap" during the full moon that she did on her own). But they bond over fighting a robber together and playing lots of hopscotch, and soon their bond is stronger than ever. It pretty quickly moves to "Romantic Interest," and all of a sudden they are flirting and kissing all the time.After a few in-game days of this, it's time for them to "woohoo" for the first time. He gives her a big dip kiss, and they go to the bed with swelling music and falling rose petals. Right as I'm wondering how birth control works in this game, since I'm not ready to raise a hybrid werewolf-vampire baby, she falls out of the bed and dies. The grim reaper shows up and takes her ghost away as I stare at my computer in shock. Apparently she died of thirst, unwilling to feed from him and not wanting to interrupt the romance to go drink.Now he's walking around the house grieving, surrounded by walls covered in all the paintings she made. He tries desperately to resurrects her while her ghost is still haunting the place, but can't find the necessary ingredients to make the potion he needs in time. He finally moves on when he finds a puppy at the animal shelter that needs a home, and starts forming a warm friendship with the zombie next door.8/10 would play out a young adult paranormal romance novel again if it weren't so incredibly slow and if each DLC wasn't ridiculously expensive.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												I've played Sims for so long now and I've played it on xbox, PSP, xbox 360, mobile and now on PC. It's one of my favorite games for several reasons. I will list the pros and cons of my overall gameplay experience below.PROS:-The requirements to play The Sims 3 are very low-You basically have full control of the Sims, which ofc is limited to the features of the game-There are optional expansion packs available to, well, expand your features-The Exchange provides additional (and free) downloadable content that are made from other players-Funny stuff happens while playing-Basically an endless amount of fun! (aka it has good replay value)-Get creative with it, no gameplay can be exactly the same because different scenarios happenCONS:-The expansion packs are pricey and sometimes don't even add too much to the game-My Sims has glitched out a few times when trying to socialize with a huge group of Sims (it might just happen to me though)Here's the first episode of my gameplay series for The Sims 3:Attack on Sims Series by Fuhn Tyme MChttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0l5EReZraTwOverall Rating: 10/10Btw, this is my first review ^^

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												Sims 3 is a lifestlye of a game, I have played with multiple families, some reaching better lives then my own haha. Its very time consuming and great for those who love multitasking. Characters can be silly to look a like to your real life self. Its nice to have a game where you can live out a dream life, with just a click.Pros:-The vast ideas of what a character could look like.-The DLCs, add more to the game when applied.-Building a home from scratch is fantanstic with the tools they provide for you.-You can download other player made sims, to give yourself the friends that also play.-You can make a story by creating and being whatever you like.-Finally got to have a loving family.Cons:-You have to buy DLCs in order to get the real good stuff.-Paranoid with teaching my children to swim, (I TOLD HER NOT TO GO IN THE POOL)-The big one, is there is no multiplayer...(I know it wouldn't happen, but it would be cool to be able to buy a sim server and host people from around the world to go into your world and live there too. But guess thats reaching for the moon)-If you own a DLC then purchase a new one, it tends to bug the previous DLCs, had to redownload a few times, so the pets would stop being invisible, really annoying when you have a pet and its yelling at you that its sad or lonely and you can't see it to help. ; -;Overall:I honestly love this game, I wish I had the time to put into it like I used too, but I will play again once I own each and every DLC so I can start over and take full advantage of them all.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												I think the Sims 3 was okay but compared to the Sims 2 it falls short in MANY ways, Originally the sims 1 was supposed to be all open neighborhoods with no loadscreen between houses,etc and all familys going simultaniously, but computers of the time just couldn't and weren't able to do that sort of processing just yet. The Sims 2 on the other hand allowed players to finally go INSIDE the Sim's places of work and to build it and even run it (to a degree) and you could even visit it with your other sims, etc -> this is one MAJOR thing I feel was left out of the Sims 3. I also don't care for how cartoonish the Sims series has become, The Sims 1 was sophisticated and articulate but the sims 2 got more childish and the sims 3 is just a complete mess, The makers of the game need to appease to all age-groups, I couldn't imagine this game making me feel any younger way into the future one far off day when I am in my 80s vs. some maxis classics like Simcity 2000. I -am- aware that will wright didn't make the Sims 3 and that that may be a HUGE part of it but still, The cartoonish-ness levels need to be brought down heavily. With that being said if I could give this a nutral rating a would, I will do a thumbs up but only because the game itself can still be a lot of fun, but only in limited amounts,

												The Sims 3 is a really awesome game. This is nearly an accepted fact, of course, because everyone loves The Sims. I'm sure that there are plent of other reviews that will tell you all about that, though. This review here is a cautionary tale, though most of you likely won't need it.There are those of you, however, who won't consider ahead of time what a money-suck this game will end up being. Do not be ashamed to admit this, I myself have this problem.You see, I'm a broke college student. Living off about $200 a month for food, I have a very bad habit of just not eating for days on end so that I can buy video games instead. The Sims 3 was the first game I bought on Steam. Prior to that, I was a dreaded Xbox gamer.I bought the base game + pets for 29.99. Let's round that up to $30, remembering that I suck at math. That's our first number. 30.I bought The Sims 3, rather than waiting just a few weeks for The Sims 4 to come out, because I have no impulse control whatsoever, and thought I'd save money by buying an older game. Perhaps I did initially save money. This, however, went down the toilet after six more DLCs, at 19.99 each. Round up to the nearest whole and our second through seventh numbers are each 20. For simplicity's sake, let's just multiply that out now to $120.But wait, there's more (there always is): The Sims does this darling little thing where it shows you all of these awesome items and worlds and stuff that you can buy with points, or whatever they're called. I don't remember at this point. Now, I know that I spent at least $50 on these, not all at once, but over time. There was some cool stuff offered, and I like cool stuff.If we add all of our lovely numbers together, we get $200, though without rounding, I suppose, it would be $199.93. This, however, is a very low guesstimate, due to the points I purchased. Keep in mind that The Sims 3 was not at all new by the time that I spent all this money.This is entirely my own fault, of course. And I do take responsibility for it. However, with 7 total DLCs (world adventures and into the future likely causing the bulk of the issues), my game was unable to run after a while. It now crashes inenvitably after just ten minutes or so of play. These DLCs are HUGE, and to anyone who plans on buying them, it is important to remember that you really need to choose which ones you really want, they do put a strain on your system.I actually bought the game thinking that it would be easy for my computer to run, since it was all sandboxy and such. I was dead wrong, and don't even know where I came up with that idea. Pretty much any other game will treat your computer with more kindness than this game will. At least in my experience.In short, I do, in fact, recommend this game. But I do so with caution. Just know what you're getting yourselves into, and also remember that the Sims may not seem as fun now as it did during your childhood. In fact, in this version, Sims can get out of the pool without a ladder. Isn't that lame? I think so. Anyhow, have fun and don't go broke.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												I think the Sims 3 was okay but compared to the Sims 2 it falls short in MANY ways, Originally the sims 1 was supposed to be all open neighborhoods with no loadscreen between houses,etc and all familys going simultaniously, but computers of the time just couldn't and weren't able to do that sort of processing just yet. The Sims 2 on the other hand allowed players to finally go INSIDE the Sim's places of work and to build it and even run it (to a degree) and you could even visit it with your other sims, etc -> this is one MAJOR thing I feel was left out of the Sims 3. I also don't care for how cartoonish the Sims series has become, The Sims 1 was sophisticated and articulate but the sims 2 got more childish and the sims 3 is just a complete mess, The makers of the game need to appease to all age-groups, I couldn't imagine this game making me feel any younger way into the future one far off day when I am in my 80s vs. some maxis classics like Simcity 2000. I -am- aware that will wright didn't make the Sims 3 and that that may be a HUGE part of it but still, The cartoonish-ness levels need to be brought down heavily. With that being said if I could give this a nutral rating a would, I will do a thumbs up but only because the game itself can still be a lot of fun, but only in limited amounts,
